content.webTitle: Scottish Premier League: Hibernian 1 - 1 Heart of Midlothian

fields.headline: Hearts take share of derby game of cards
fields.bodyText: Hibernian and Hearts proved that the Scottish game is still alive and kicking, literally, in the capital at least with an Edinburgh derby that was laced with goals, bookings and all the usual controversy. "It was a typical derby - frantic, with loads of fouls, sweat and effort and the referee could have worn out his yellow cards," said the Hearts manager Craig Levein. "But I did feel we were the better side and could have won." Derek Riordan's goal, a glorious 30-yard strike, was fit to win any match, but a Steven Pressley penalty, after a clumsy Colin Murdock challenge on Mark de Vries 30 seconds into the second half, ensured the points were shared. Hearts might have won it but for a fine save by Daniel Andersson, who touched a Paul Hartley free-kick on to the post after 70 minutes. Scott Brown, Jarkko Wiss and Murdock of Hibs were booked after 13, 16 and 51 minutes with the first and last lucky not to be sent off for nasty fouls. The same could also have been said of Hearts' Patrick Kisnorbo and Hartley, who were fortunate to have been shown merely yellow cards. Alan Maybury escaped all punishment for an apparent off-the-ball punch at Brown but may find Levein, or even the SFA's video review panel, dispensing justice later. "I'm disappointed that none of the three officials saw the incident between Maybury and Brown," the Hibernian manager Bobby Williamson said. "But it's not up to me what happens next." Levein best summed up an entertaining if seldom vintage match when he added: "No one expected a classic - and we didn't get one." Man of the match : Steven Pressley (Hearts)
